review_title: Does not offer what competitors can
job_title: Radiology Tech Aide and Receptionist in Broomall, PA
pros: Most of the people I work with directly are hard workers and will do any thing for you. I've met a lot of great people that I have developed close friendships with.
cons: Crozer/Prospect does not give raises in my experience personally. The last raise we received was after Prospect took over and that was called a "cost of living increase" which provided me with an extra 10 CENTS in my bi-weekly paycheck. We are also extremely short staffed with the better employees being taken advantage of (forced to work alone, work shifts they were not hired for, work longer days with zero notice when people call out, etc.)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Turnersville, NJ
pros: Organization with good intentions but faced with multiple challenges based on geography and nature of healthcare reform. Many talented staff and managers, but systematically are being exited for short-sighted cost-savings. Used to have excellent benefits and employee recognition programs, but clearly on the downslide and will probably expedite with new for-profit ownership.
cons: Navigating and managing change, particularly relative to employee engagement and development is certainly not a leadership strength. In fact the "Peter Principle" may have a current case study in the making. Morale and confusion seem to regularly accompany lack of fruitful completion of a good number of well-intended project and improvement initiatives. Loyalty to long-time accountable contributors is a thing of the past. Many adversarial relationships internally.

job_title: Staff RN in Upland, Chester, PA
pros: Fellow co-workers have each other's back - at least in my experience. There used to be a ton of great things about Crozer.  Each year they omit more and more perks, They still give $4,000 to full time employees for education........Thats all I can come up with.
cons: Greedy and petty management. Their for-profit mentality is evident. I have worked here well over 10 years and can not stand it another minute. I am actively job-hunting. The place is a Troll Hole, the benefits suck and frankly, I'm embarrassed to work there. If you want to feel like driving into a tree every time you go to work, get a job at Crozer : )

job_title: MA/Phlebotomist in Glen Mills, PA
pros: Other than the fantastic management in our particular office, and the incredible medical insurance I understand isn't even that great anymore, the amount of work expected with the nearly minimum wage pay is disgusting. If it weren't for people actually caring about patients (which isn't the same now either) you would have lost a ton of employees.
cons: Low pay. No chance at advancement. Ridiculous hour expectations with little to no breaks in a shift. Ridiculous expectations to help the Drs meet their patient goals and no idea how much the actual MA's perform to achieve that, but they are the ones who get their big fat commission checks, while we continue to slave away doing all of the work when they are in and out of a room in less than 10 minutes.

review_title: A diamond in A LOT of rough...
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Upper Darby, PA
pros: Great starting pay for most positions.
cons: Decision making and communication is one major downfall of this organization. The higher ups either don’t know, or don’t care about non financial issues of the organization. Everyone is replaceable and the workloads are often dumped in the laps of unexpected employees with little explanation. Too much strife between union and non union. It often feels like you are sinking and you look for help, but then you are comforted by the fact that everyone is sinking. All aboard the Titanic.. I mean welcome to Crozer.

job_title: RN NURSE in Upland, Chester, PA
pros: Previously paid higher than counterparts.
cons: New management over last 3 - 4 years based heavily on bullying, criticism and threats.  Very negative work environment.  Continuous new rules made with very vague outlines as to procedures.  Continuous decreases in staffing leading to multiple issues in patient and staff safety and infection control.  Education decreased dramatically. Main hospital based in community where gunshots are heard on regular basis, high drug usage and trade.

review_title: Great first job experience to bulk resume
job_title: Intensive Case Manager in Chester, PA
pros: The medical benefits are actually decent, if you have Crozer doctors. It's good for those first out of college.
cons: It's all about the bottom dollar with Crozer. They will burn you out and use all you have just to make their money. But, if any money is lost, it's on you and nothing else. In my position it was all about reimbursements. It was nice to get the experience, but that's all I got from it.

review_title: Depressing medical office environment. Not what you want, I can guarantee that.
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Ridley Park, PA
pros: The best (and worst) thing you have is your co-workers. Room for advancement is there, however, salary doesn't move much and to be treated poorly, it's not really worth it.
cons:
Where do I start?

Your office will be perpetually short-staffed, and resumes pour in but nobody will be hired because upper management will not approve another MA position, and yet they have no problem adding another physician to the practice. 

Many employees have mental health problems relative to the constant inability to complete their work yet there is always something else being added to the top of your pile and the pressure is unreal. Point: little to no help given when needed. See more patients but don't expect more resources to help you do your job. Travel 15 miles to one office 1 day, 10 to another office the next 2 days, finish out the week back 15 miles away and they don't pay you for travel. You have to pay to park at the hospitals except 1 even if you work there and Crozer Chester is about $30 monthly. RIP OFF! 

Management is mostly concerned with losing the jobs they aren't qualified for (my manager has no qualifications, and it reflects in the office), and they don't care who they step on or ruin in the process of keeping their job. There was constant change in infrastructure and at one point we did not have a department head for almost a year, which makes using the chain of command for office problems impossible. SO many employees on FMLA for one reason or another (maybe lack of help and resources? think about it....) and FAR too many PERSONAL politics for a medical office that your work environment will become hostile. Favoritism is rampant and not just among the physicians. One of my co-workers comes to work high on prescription anxiety medication, nodding out, falling asleep at her desk, and despite multiple complaints from 4 or 5 people in the office INCLUDING 2 of the doctors, she is still employed. They are cover-up artists at CKHN, from clinical supervisor all the way up to administrative director. The things they allow in this organization...... it's really opened up my eyes to how big business works. The almighty dollar truly rules. 

The health benefits are good, they even cover IVF. Not usually any out of pocket for surgery or maternity care and you get access to the Healthplex gym at a discount albeit not a great one. You do have to use all CK physicians to get the most out of your benefits and you have to be careful if you need access to a specialist they don't have. There are a lot of changes happening within the network and Crozer was recently bought and have been attending many meetings, training and classes. 

CKHS facilities are "community-based" which means patients can treat you however they want and your providers will not dismiss them: the $3 they're getting from Keystone First is much more important than you bursting into tears at work. There is a lot of pressure to invoke your collections capabilities and they keep seeing these patients while their balances grow and grow. Pay is awfully low for any non-union position but then again I heard the nurses complaining about as much as the MA's. It doesn't matter how much experience you have when you first join Crozer because they will start you at an almost insulting rate of pay. However, when you need a job and it is offered, there is no question whether or not you will take the position. There was a raise in the past year, but for many years straight there was not. I know for a fact that I'm making close to what other employees who have been around 10-plus years are making. 

The doctors, where do I begin? Some of them are fantastic. I mean truly great individuals and physicians. Some are terrible people but great doctors. A few are crap all around.  I got lucky with good ones for the most part but have encountered mean people here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Springfield, PA
pros: No micromanagement. Good quality of patient care. Low therapist to patient expectations and productivity standards. Great co-workers.
cons: Building  and department upkeep is poor. Equipment requests are ignored. There is little to no technology available or advancement. Communication, especially with management, is very lacking. We are notoriously underpaid. Our suggestions and concerns seem unheard by management.

job_title: Staff RN in Drexel Hill, PA
pros: Those that have worked there a long time are friendly and genuinely care about the patients.
cons: Staffing is HORRIBLE.  Constantly short staffed because there are no nurses left to help because upper management laid them off.  Management does not value employees, constantly wants them to do more for less.  PCT's are worked to the bone.  RN's try to help but there is too much on their plates as well.  Pension has been frozen for a while.  Pay raises stink. Equipment is broken or falling apart.

review_title: a once great place to work keeps getting worse
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chester, PA
pros: great benefits up to 5 weeks vacation for over 20 years of service ,12 sick days and 12 legal/personal days off. employee pharmacy is around half the price of big chain pharmacies .
cons: Since the above mentioned benefits cost money many fear their position may be reduced to part time or be outsourced to a company with much less generous benefits . We have gone many years with no raises so with ever increasing costs of benefits we are taking home less and less . Management seems clueless as to what it takes to get the job done ,not enough employees to get things done properly, many people have already left because things are so bad and they are not replaced but they still expect all the work to be done with fewer and fewer people ,they use fear , intimidation, threats and bullying to get things  done. That a job gets done is more important than it's quality. A lot of the equipment is ancient and broken, The State and other inspectors need to just show up without warning to see what really goes on.

review_title: If I could give it a zero,  I would
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chester, PA
pros: NONE, ZERO, ZILCH, NADA, NOTHING
cons: They treat longtime, loyal employees like dirt. They hire morons to run the place and that is why it is being run into the ground. They have managers that do illegal things all the time and when reported to HR, they just ignore the problems, but god-forbid anyone clock in or out a minute late and they get their hands slapped. No raises for over 5 years, but upper admins make over a million or close to it with regular raises. working conditions are horrible. There are roaches that fall from ceiling, even onto patients, they are in desk drawers, crawling on tables, there are mice, the place is never cleaned unless there is a site surveyor coming. I've heard horror stories from physicians and staff about the deplorable conditions on the medical floors and none of them will even bring their own families here for treatment. That is pretty bad. Our insurance is horrible. We have insane deductibles, high copays and they lied to us about how much this would cost us. Not to mention the $35 a month to park and no compensation for that. No way to move up around here unless you are friends with a higher up or if you are a nasty person. It doesn't pay to be nice around here. I cold go on and on...
